description: From Middle English froward, fraward, equivalent to fro +‎ -ward. Compare Old English fromweard, framweard (“turned away, having the back turned”).

adjectives.description: froward (comparative more froward, superlative most froward)

entries.meaning: (archaic, literary) Disobedient, contrary, unmanageable; difficult to deal with; with an evil disposition.
examples: But in the meanwhile, for fear lest if he would wax never the better he would wax much the worse; and from gentle, smooth, sweet, and courteous, might wax angry, rough, froward, and sour, and thereupon be troublous and tedious to the world to make fair weather with; they give him fair words for the while and put him in good comfort, and let him for the rest take his own chance.
